awd_titl_txt: Advancing the Research Profile of Small and Mid-Sized Historically Black Colleges and Universities Through a Virtual Proposal Development Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Jackson State University will establish a virtual proposal development center (VPDC) to support small and midsized Historically Black Colleges and Universities by providing guidance to faculty at participating institutions in pre-proposal activities, including identification of appropriate funding opportunities and development of research concepts. The project aligns with the goal of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program to provide assistance to its community to increase faculty research capacity. The project's potential for transformative impact is based both on its uniqueness as an approach to supporting small, resource-impoverished institutions and on the promise it offers to increase collaborations between scholars at different institutions.  The structure of the project will encourage collaborations between institutions and across science, technology, engineering and mathematics disciplines. 

The specific objectives of the VPDC are the following: (1) identifying the specific pre-proposal and proposal preparation needs of the targeted institutions; (2) developing mechanisms for identifying appropriate funding opportunities for the targeted institutions; (3) building a repository of proposal preparation materials; (4) assisting faculty at targeted institutions to develop concepts in line with published solicitations; and (5) establishing mechanisms for self-sustaining proposal development at participating institutions, including peer-mentoring, peer review teams, and mentoring relationships between faculty and sponsored research personnel at participating institutions.  Each cohort of faculty and sponsored-research staff will complete a twelve-week online course and take part in at least one three-day writing retreat.  An ongoing evaluation will assess whether or not the VPDC meets the specific needs of the participating institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to increase the proposal productivity of faculty at small and mid-sized HBCUs through implementation of an online training program and provision of proposal development support services to faculty. It developed a learning-training model, the Virtual Proposal Development Center, that can be scaled-up to include more faculty at teaching-focused institutions that serve large populations of underrepresented minority students.

 

The main thrust of this program was providing training and professional development for faculty at HBCUs, especially at teaching-focused HBCUs. At the heart of the project was a training program for drafting competitive research proposals. The project provided self-paced online instruction that walked participants through the basics of drafting and preparing a proposal for research funding and offered additional proposal development support services including solicitation matching, feedback on proposals drafts, external editing assistance, and critiques of drafts by external reviewers.

 

The program directly contacted 143 faculty members at HBCUs and contacted research-related administrators and/or deans at 12 HBCUs. These efforts produced a pool of faculty who completed applications, participated in an interview or conversation with the program development specialist, and/or received some form of proposal development services (e.g., completion of the online training course, provision of funding opportunities targeted to the participants’ interests/expertise, completion of a concept paper by the participant, review or editing of a proposal or concept paper). 

 

Project Structure

The project engaged in the following major activities:

●       Creation of an online training program centered around a proposal development course to teach faculty participants how to develop competitive research proposals.

●       Identification of prospective participating institutions, i.e., teaching-focused small and mid-sized HBCUs, and an assessment of their proposal development needs.

●       Identification and recruitment of faculty participants at participating institutions to complete training and draft competitive research proposals.

●       Provision of proposal development support services to faculty participants including feedback on drafts of proposals.

●       On-going assessment of the efficacy of the training program and the potential to scale-up the Virtual Proposal Development Center.

 

The VPDC team identified potential participating HBCUs based on the following criteria: (1) external funding received per year and (2) Carnegie-designation and previous engagement, selecting HBCUs that earned some external funding but were not among the top ten HBCU recipients and were not designated as R2 institutions. The VPDC developed an institutional survey that encompassed available grant-writing services on the participating institutions’ campuses and that assessed institutional incentives and impediments to faculty grant-writing and overall grant-writing productivity. The team also collected data about target institutions amount, sources, and types of federal grant funding via NCES, IPEDS, and NIH Data Reporter to provide base-line data for those institutions.

 

The team used web-based video conferences to recruit participants, who were asked to complete an IRB consent form as well as the needs assessment survey. The needs assessment survey asked participants to self-report their knowledge and experience levels as well as available pre-award services on their campuses and captured their research interests and/or concepts. Participants also participated in an introductory conversation with the program development specialist and completed an application.

 

Project Impacts

This pilot project elicited initial interest but less follow-through from faculty regardless of the number of follow-up contacts by the program specialist. The literature engages with the idea of motivations and impediments to proposal submission. Typical motivating factors are impact on career advancement (e.g. tenure and promotion), institutional norms and expectations, institutional rules (e.g., use of external funding to contribute to salary), interest in research activities or training-focused intervention, and expectations for research autonomy. Typical impediments are scarcity of time (e.g. course-loads, administrative/advising responsibilities, and familial obligations); lack of familiarity with the process; and under-resourced pre-award offices.

The VPDC Pilot sought to scale a successful proposal writing program at one R2 HBCU into a broader network of pre-proposal training and services for multiple teaching-focused (PUI) HBCUs. It attempted to remove or reduce the impact of lack of familiarity with the process and under-provisioned pre-award services offices. However, it could not reduce potentially the greatest impediment, lack of time, by providing course releases, summer funding, etc. Nor could it substantially alter the institutional rules and norms at PUI HBCUs that might contribute to motivation and perseverance.

This project has significant impact for teaching-focused primarily undergraduate institutions. At many of these institutions, faculty must navigate heavy teaching loads with minimal teaching assistance and often feel as if they do not have the time or resources to write competitive research funding proposals. This project has the potential to meet faculty where they are, specifically those at institutions that may have scant resources available.
